   Now assume $\bigcap_{A_i \in A} A_i \neq \emptyset$, so at least one element could appear in more than one set in $A$. We can define a one-one function from $\bigcup_{A_i \in A} A_i$ into the disjoint union $\bigsqcup_{A_i \in A} A_i = \bigcup_{A_i \in A} (\{ i \} \times A_i)$ such that $H: \bigcup_{A_i \in A} A_i \xrightarrow[]{1-1} \bigsqcup_{A_i \in A} A_i$ where:
   
      - For each element $x \in \bigsqcup_{A_i \in A} A_i$, pick $i \in \mathbb{P}$ such that $x \in A_i$
      
      - Then assign $x$ to $(i, x) \in \{ i \} \times A_i$
  
   Therefore by @thm-composition-functions-one-one $\Psi \circ H: \bigcup_{A_i \in A} A_i \xrightarrow[]{1-1} \mathbb{P}$. So $\bigcup_{A_i \in A} A_i \leq \mathbb{P}$.
   
   Furthermore, let's $M: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[]{1-1} \bigcup_{A_i \in A} A_i$ such that $M(i) = a_i$ where $a_i \in A_i$. So $\mathbb{P} \leq \bigcup_{A_i \in A} A_i$.
   
   Finally by @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem $\bigcup_{A_i \in A} A_i \approx \mathbb{P}$.
   
:::

::: {#thm-denumerable-sets}

The following sets are denumerable:

a. The set $\mathbb{Z}$ of all integers
b. The set $\mathbb{Q}^+$ of all positive rational integers
c. The set $\mathbb{Q}$ of all rational numbers

:::

::: {.proof}

a. We can build $F$ such that $F: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathbb{Z}$ where:

   $$F(p) = \begin{cases}
              0             & \text{ if } p = 1 \\
              \frac{p}{2}   & \text{ if } p = 2k \\
             -\frac{p-1}{2} & \text{ if } p = 2k + 1
            \end{cases}$$
   
   In code using the R programming language:

   ```{r}
   #| lst-label: lst-p-to-z
   #| lst-cap: Bijection between $\mathbb{P}$ and $\mathbb{Z}$
   #| echo: true

   p_to_z <- function(p) {
   
     if (p == 1) {
      z = 0
     } else if (p %% 2 == 0) {
      z = p / 2
     } else {
      z = -((p - 1) / 2)
     }
     
    return(z)
    
   }

   # Test with p = 9
   p_to_z(p = 9)
   ```

b. For this proof check out [@aigner_proofs_2018, chap. 19] which explains the Calkin–Wilf listing. Create the following tree (See @fig-calkin-wilf-listing-as-a-tree):

   ![Calkin–Wilf listing as a tree](images/fig-calkin–wilf-listing-as-a-tree.png){#fig-calkin-wilf-listing-as-a-tree fig-align="center" width=70%}
   
   Where $\frac{1}{1}$ is at the top of the tree and every node $\frac{i}{j}$ has 2 sons:
   
      - The left son is $\frac{i}{i + j}$
      - The right son is $\frac{i + j}{j}$
   
   Therefore we can generate the list $\frac{1}{1}, \frac{1}{2}, \frac{2}{1}, \frac{1}{3}, \frac{3}{2}, \frac{2}{3}, \frac{3}{1}, \frac{1}{4}, \frac{4}{3}, \frac{3}{5}, \frac{5}{2}, \frac{2}{5}, \frac{5}{3}, \frac{3}{4}, \frac{4}{1} \ldots$
   
   Also we have the following properties:
   
      - All fractions in the tree are reduced, that is if $gcd(i, j) = 1$ then $gcd(i, i + j) = 1$ and $gcd(i + j, j) = 1$ where $gcd$ is the greatest common divisor and is defined as $gcd(i,j) = max\{ d \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0} \mid d | i \land d | j \}$
      
      - Every reduced fraction appears at least once. If $\frac{i}{j} \neq 1$ then $i > j$ or $i < j$.
      
          - If $i > j$ then it is the right son of $\frac{i - j}{j}$ where $gcd(i - j, j) = 1$
          - If $i < j$ then it is the left son of $\frac{i}{j - i}$ where $gcd(i, j - i) = 1$
          
        Therefore, by applying this rule leads as back to $\frac{1}{1}$. This provides a unique finite path back to the root.
      
      - Every reduced fraction appears exactly once. If $\frac{i}{j} \neq 1$ then $i > j$ or $i < j$. Therefore $\frac{i}{j}$ can only have one unique parent:
      
          - If $i > j$ then the unique parent is $\frac{i - j}{j}$
          - If $i < j$ then the unique parent is $\frac{i}{j - i}$
          
   So we can obtain the sequence using [@fig-calkin-wilf-listing-as-a-tree] by starting at the root and then visiting all nodes at each level from left to right:
   
   $$\frac{1}{1}, \frac{1}{2}, \frac{2}{1}, \frac{1}{3}, \frac{3}{2}, \frac{2}{3}, \frac{3}{1}, \frac{1}{4}, \frac{4}{3}, \frac{3}{5}, \frac{5}{2}, \frac{2}{5}, \frac{5}{3}, \frac{3}{4}, \frac{4}{1}, \ldots$$
         
    - The denominator of the $n$-th fraction equals the numerator of the $n+1$-th fraction in the above list.
    
       - It is true for the first and second position in the list
       - If $\frac{i}{j}$ is a left son the father is $\frac{i}{j-i}$ and the right son is $\frac{j}{j-i}$ 
       
       - If $\frac{i}{j}$ is a right son and at the right boundary then $j=1$ and the next fraction in the list is at the left boundary where the numerator is $1$
       
       - If $\frac{i}{j}$ is a right son and at the interior where the next fraction is $\frac{i^{'}}{j^{'}}$ then the father of $\frac{i}{j}$ is $\frac{i-j}{j}$ and the father of $\frac{i^{'}}{j^{'}}$ is $\frac{i^{'}}{j^{'}-i^{'}}$.
       
          - In this case we apply an argument by induction where in the case of the fathers we have that $j = i^{'}$   
   
   But how we can obtain a function $S(y)$ as described in [@def-peano-system] where $y \in \mathbb{Q}_{>0}$?
   
   In our tree we have that:
   
   ![Calkin–Wilf branch](images/fig-calkin–wilf-branch.png){#fig-calkin-wilf-branch fig-align="center" width=20%}
   
   If $x = \frac{i}{j}$ then $x + 1 = \frac{i+j}{j}$. Also $x + 1 = \frac{\frac{i+j}{i}}{\frac{j}{i}} = \frac{\frac{i+j}{i}}{\frac{1}{x}}$ so $\frac{x+1}{x} = \frac{i+j}{i}$ and $\frac{x}{x+1} = \frac{i}{i+j}$.
   
   Therefore we have that:
   
   ![Calkin–Wilf alternative branch representation](images/fig-calkin–wilf-branch-rational.png){#fig-calkin-wilf-branch-rational fig-align="center" width=20%}
   
   In that way we can expand the tree to identify which is the next fraction in the list in the following way for the $k$ level:
   
   ![Calkin–Wilf alternative branch representation expansion](images/fig-calkin–wilf-branch-rational-expansion.png){#fig-calkin-wilf-branch-rational-expansion fig-align="center" width=70%}

   Therefore, if $y = \frac{x}{x+1} + k$ then $k = \left\lfloor y \right\rfloor$ is the integral part of $y$ and $\frac{x}{x+1} = \{y\}$ is fractional part of $y$ where $y = \{y\} + \left\lfloor y \right\rfloor$.
   
   So $\frac{x + 1}{kx + (k+1)} = \frac{x + 1}{1 + k(x+1)} = \frac{1}{\frac{1}{x+1} + k} = \frac{1}{1 - \frac{x}{x+1} + k} = \frac{1}{1 - \{y\} + \left\lfloor y \right\rfloor}$.
   
   This means that $S(y) = \frac{1}{1 - \{y\} + \left\lfloor y \right\rfloor} = \frac{1}{2\left\lfloor y \right\rfloor - y + 1}$ or alternatively $y_1 = \frac{1}{1}$ and $y_{n+1} = \frac{1}{2\left\lfloor y_n \right\rfloor - y_n + 1}$.
   
   Now, how you can obtain the position $k$ in the list using the Calkin–Wilf tree?
   
   Think of each branch as left $(0)$ or right $(1)$ where the root, $\frac{1}{1}$, is associated with $1$. So for example to reach $\frac{5}{2}$ we can represent it as $RLRR$ or $1011$ where $\frac{5}{2}$ is in the position $11$ in the tree and the representation of $11$ in base 2 is $1011$
   
   So the function will be as follows:
   
      - $r_0 = \frac{0}{1}$
      - $r_n = \begin{cases}
               \frac{i}{i + j} & \text{ if } k_2(n) = 0 \\
               \frac{i + j}{j} & \text{ if } k_2(n) = 1
               \end{cases}$
      
      Where, $0 < n \leq k$, $r_{n-1} = \frac{i}{j}$, $k_2$ is the binary representation of $k$ and $k_2(n)$ is the $n$ element from left to right in the binary representation of $k$.
      
      For example let $k = 4$ and $n = 2$. So $4_2 = 100$, $k_4(2) = 0$ and $r_2 = \frac{1}{2}$ where $r_1 = \frac{1}{1}$. In that way if you want to know $r_4$ you use $r_0$ to calculate $r_1$, $r_1$ to calculate $r_2$, $r_2$ to calculate $r_3$ and $r_3$ to finally calculate $r_4$.
      
      In @lst-p-to-q-positive it is pointed out a possible way to find the $k$ position in the Calkin–Wilf tree using the R programming language.
   
   ```{r}
   #| lst-label: lst-p-to-q-positive
   #| lst-cap: Finding the position of the k rational number in the Calkin–Wilf tree
   #| echo: true

   p_to_q_positive <- function(p) {
 
   # Function to find the binary representation
   decimal_to_binary <- function(decimal_num) {
   
     binary_num <- integer(0)
  
     while (decimal_num > 0) {
     remainder <- decimal_num %% 2
     binary_num <- c(remainder, binary_num) # Add at the beginning
     decimal_num <- decimal_num %/% 2
     
     }
  
     return(binary_num)
  
    }
 
    # Binary representation of the position
    position_to_binary <- decimal_to_binary(decimal_num = p)
    # Root
    frac <- c(0,1)
 
    for (i in position_to_binary) {
  
      if (i == 0) {
      frac[2] <- frac[1] + frac[2] 
      } else {
        frac[1] <- frac[1] + frac[2] 
      }
  
     }
 
    return(frac)
 
    }

    # Test with k=4
    p_to_q_positive(p = 4)
   ```
c. By thm-denumerable-sets b. let $\Phi$ be a one-one correspondence between $\mathbb{Q}^+$ and $\mathbb{P}$. Then define:

   $$\Psi(z) = \begin{cases}
                \Phi(z)   & \text{ if }  z \in \mathbb{Z}^+ \\
                0         & \text{ if }  z = 0 \\
                -\Phi(-z) & \text{ if } -z \in \mathbb{Z}^+
               \end{cases}$$

   Then $\Psi: \mathbb{Z} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathbb{Q}$. In code using the R programming language:

   ```{r}
   #| lst-label: lst-z-to-q
   #| lst-cap: Bijection between $\mathbb{Z}$ and $\mathbb{Q}$
   #| echo: true

   z_to_q <- function(z) {
    
    if (z > 0) {
      r = p_to_q_positive(p = z)
     } else if (z < 0) {
      r = p_to_q_positive(p = -z)
      r[1] = -r[1]
     } else {
      r = 0
     }
    
     return(r)
    
   }

   # Test with z=-4
   z_to_q(z = -4)
   ```
   But by @thm-denumerable-sets a. $\mathbb{P} \approx \mathbb{Z}$. Hence, $\mathbb{P} \approx \mathbb{Q}$. In code using the R programming language:
   
   ```{r}
   #| lst-label: lst-p-to-q
   #| lst-cap: Bijection between $\mathbb{P}$ and $\mathbb{Q}$
   #| echo: true

   # Test with p = 9
   9 |> 
    p_to_z() |> 
    z_to_q()
   ```
:::

::: {#nte-notation-cardinal-numbers .callout-note}

## Notations cardinal numbers

The cardinal number $\mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P})$ is traditionally denoted by $\aleph_0$. Thus, all denumerable sets have cardinal numbers $\aleph_0$. 

By @exr-denumerable-set-1 the only cardinal numbers smaller than $\aleph_0$ are the finite cardinal numbers.

By @exr-denumerable-sets 1. $\aleph_0$ is the smallest infinite cardinal number.

By @thm-cantor-theorem the cardinal number of $\mathscr{P}(\mathbb{P})$ is bigger that $\aleph_0$

:::

Let $\mathbb{R}$ denote the set of real numbers.

::: {#thm-half-open-interval-0-1}

The half-open interval $[0,1) = \{x \mid x \in \mathbb{R} \land 0 \leq x < 1 \}$ is not denumerable.

:::

::: {.proof}

Assume that $[0,1)$ is denumerable. Let $\Psi: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} [0,1)$. Denote $\Psi(n) = r_n$ for each $n \in \mathbb{P}$. Each $r_n$ can be represented by an infinite decimal $.a_{n1}a_{n2}a_{n3}\ldots$ where $a_{nm} \in \{ 0, 1, \ldots, 9 \}$ and $m \in \mathbb{P}$.

Also because infinite decimals with an infinite tail of $9$'s, such as $0.427999\ldots$, represent the same number as another decimal with an infinite tail of $0$'s, in the example $0.248000\ldots$, we avoid decimal expansions that terminate in repeating $9$'s.

So we have that:

\begin{align*}
r_1 & = \; .a_{11}a_{12}a_{13}\ldots \\
r_2 & = \; .a_{21}a_{22}a_{23}\ldots \\
r_3 & = \; .a_{31}a_{32}a_{33}\ldots \\
& \;\; \vdots
\end{align*}

Now, define a new decimal $.c_1c_2c_3\ldots$ such that:

$$c_n = \begin{cases}
         0 & \text{ if } a_{nn} \neq 0 \\
         1 & \text{ if } a_{nn} = 0
        \end{cases}$$

Then the decimal $.c_1c_2c_3\ldots$ differs from each decimal $r_n$ in the $n$-th place. Hence, $.c_1c_2c_3\ldots$ does not appear in the list, contradicting the assumption that $\Psi: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} [0,1)$.  

:::

By a generalized interval, we shall mean a set of real numbers of nay of the following forms:

\begin{align*}
 [a,b] & = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a \leq x \leq b \} \\
 (a,b) & = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a < x < b \} \\
 [a,b) & = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a \leq x < b \} \\
 (a,b] & = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a < x \leq b \} \\
 [a,\infty) & = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a \leq x \} \\
 (a,\infty) & = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid a < x \} \\
 (-\infty, a] & = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid x \leq a \} \\
 (-\infty, a) & = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} \mid x < a \}
\end{align*}

::: {#thm-generalized-intervals-r-equinumerous}

All generalized intervals are equinumerous with each other and with the whole set $\mathbb{R}$ of real numbers.

:::

::: {.proof}

1. First, we map $(a, b)$ into $(c, d)$.

   To do that we map $(a, b)$ into $(0, 1)$. Take $x \in (a, b)$ and shift $x$ to the left by $a$ applying $x - a$ and then scale it by $b - a$ such that $\frac{x - a}{b - a}$:

   \begin{align*}
    a & < x < b \\
    0 & < x - a < b - a \\
    0 & < \frac{x - a}{b-a} < 1
   \end{align*}

   Then scale by the interval length $d-c$ and shift to the starting point $c$:
   
   \begin{align*}
    0 & < \frac{x - a}{b-a} < 1 \\
    0 & < (d-c)\frac{x - a}{b-a} < d-c \\
    c & < (d-c)\frac{x - a}{b-a} + c < d \\
   \end{align*}
   
   So an specific bijection between $(a,b)$ and $(c,d)$ is $(d-c)\frac{x - a}{b-a} + c$. Therefore $(a,b) \approx (c,d)$.

2. Second, we map $(0, 1)$ into $(0, \infty)$ in the following way:

   \begin{align*}
    0 & < x < 1 \\
    -1 & < -x < 0 \\
    0 & < 1-x < 1 \\
    1 & < \frac{1}{1-x} \\
    0 & < \frac{1}{1-x} - 1
   \end{align*}

   Therefore $\frac{1}{1-x} - 1 \in (0, \infty)$ and $(0, 1) \approx (0, \infty)$ where the explicity bijection is $\frac{1}{1-x} - 1$.
   
   Furthermore, we can map $(0, 1)$ into $(a, \infty)$ with $\frac{1}{1-x} - 1 + a$.
   
   Also, we can map $(0, 1)$ into $(-\infty, 0)$ with:
   
   \begin{align*}
    0 & < \frac{1}{1-x} - 1 \\
    0 & > -\left( \frac{1}{1-x} - 1 \right)
   \end{align*}
   
   So, we can map $(0, 1)$ into $(-\infty, a)$ with $-\left( \frac{1}{1-x} - 1 \right) + a$.
   
3. Third, we map $(-1, 1)$ into $\mathbb{R}$ in the following way:

   $$\Psi(u) = \begin{cases}
                \frac{1}{1-x} - 1 & \text{ if } u \in (0,1) \\
                0                 & \text{ if } u = 0 \\
                -\frac{1}{1-(-x)} - 1 & \text{ if } u \in (-1,0)
               \end{cases}$$
   
   Therefore, $(-1,1) \approx \mathbb{R}$.

4. Now, assume $I$ is a generalized interval. So, there is some interval $(a,b)$ included in $I$ such that $(a,b) \subseteq I$. 

   By the above results $(a,b) \approx (-1,1)$ so $(-1,1) \leq I$. Also because $\mathbb{R} \approx (-1,1)$ then $\mathbb{R} \leq I$.
   
   Converserly, because $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ then $I \leq \mathbb{R}$
   
   By @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem $I \approx \mathbb{R}$.
  
:::

::: {#exr-set-includes-generalized-interval}

1. If $A \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and $A$ includes some generalized interval, $I \subseteq A$, prove that $A \approx \mathbb{R}$.

:::

::: {#sol-set-includes-generalized-interval}

Because $A \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ then $A \leq \mathbb{R}$.

Because $I \subseteq A$ then $I \leq A$. Also $\mathbb{R} \approx I$ so $\mathbb{R} \leq A$.

By @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem $A \approx \mathbb{R}$. 

:::

::: {#nte-notation-cardinal-number-r .callout-note}

The symbol $\mathfrak{c}$ is used to denote $\mathscr{K}(\mathbb{R})$, the cardinal number of $\mathbb{R}$. $\mathfrak{c}$ is called the power of continuum.

From @thm-generalized-intervals-r-equinumerous all generalized intervals have cardinal number $\mathfrak{c}$. 

From @thm-half-open-interval-0-1 $\aleph_0 <_K \mathfrak{c}$.

Whether there is a cardinal number between $\aleph_0$ and $\mathfrak{c}$ is a long-standing mathematical problem called the continuum hypothesis. 

:::

The fact proved in @thm-half-open-interval-0-1 that $\mathbb{P} < \mathbb{R}$ is not new. By @thm-cantor-theorem $\mathbb{P} < \mathscr{P}(\mathbb{P})$ and the following theorem tell us that this result is equivalent to $\mathbb{P} < \mathbb{R}$.

::: {#thm-equinumerous-r-power-set-p}

$\mathbb{R} \approx \mathscr{P}(\mathbb{P})$. That is the set of real numbers is equinumerous with the set of all sets of positive numbers.

:::

::: {.proof}

By @thm-characteristic-function $\{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}} \approx \mathscr{P}(\mathbb{P})$.

Hence we can prove that $\mathbb{R} \approx \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}}$.

Since $\mathbb{R} \approx [0,1)$ by @thm-generalized-intervals-r-equinumerous, it suffices to prove that $[0,1) \approx \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}}$.

Any number in $[0,1)$ has an infinite binary expansion just as it has an infinite decimal representation. In the case of 2 binary representations for the same number, we discard the representation with an infinite tail of $1$'s.

Every infinite binary (See @sec-appendix-h) representation can be considered to be an element of $\{ 0, 1\}^{\mathbb{P}} = \{ f \mid f: \mathbb{P} \longrightarrow \{ 0, 1\} \}$. For example $0.5$ in base $10$, $(0.5)_{10}$, can be represented in base $2$ as $0.1000\ldots$, $(0.1000\ldots)_2$, where it has an associated $f: \mathbb{P} \longrightarrow \{ 0, 1\}$ such that $1 = f(1), 0 = f(2), 0 = f(3), 0 = f(4), \ldots$. Thus, we have a one-one correspondence between $[0, 1)$ and a subset of $\{ 0, 1\}^{\mathbb{P}}$ because those binary representations with infinite tails of $1$'s were not used. For example $0.4999\ldots$ in base $10$, $(0.4999\ldots)_{10}$, represented in base $2$ as $0.0111\ldots$, $(0.0111\ldots)_2$, is not considered. Therefore, that range of this one-one correspondence is not equal to the range of $\{ 0, 1\}^{\mathbb{P}}$. So, $G: [0,1) \xrightarrow[]{1-1} \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}}$ and $[0,1) \leq \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}}$.

Conversely, let's represent the numbers in $[0,1)$ in base $3$. So, for example $0.5$ in base $10$, $(0.5)_{10}$,is represented as $0.111\ldots$ in base $3$, $(0.111\ldots)_{3}$ and $0.1$ in base $10$, $(0.1)_{10}$,is represented as $00220022\ldots$ in base $3$, $00220022\ldots)_{3}$. Then with each element $g$ in $\{ 0, 1\}^{\mathbb{P}}$ we associate the real number in $[0,1)$ the base $3$ representation provided by $0.g(1)g(2)\ldots$ where $g(i) \neq 2$. So, $H: \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}} \xrightarrow[]{1-1} [0,1)$ taking into account that numbers like $0.1$ represented in base $3$ as $00220022\ldots)_{3}$ are not part of the range of this one-one correspondence. Therefore, $[0,1) \geq \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}}$. 

Because, $[0,1) \leq \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}}$ and $[0,1) \geq \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}}$ then by @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem $[0,1) \approx \{ 0, 1 \}^{\mathbb{P}}$.
:::

::: {#lem-equinumerous-set}

For any sets $A$ and $B$, there exist sets $A_1$, $B_1$ such that $A_1 \approx A$, $B_1 \approx B$ and $A_1 \cap B_1 = \emptyset$.

:::

::: {.proof}

Let $A_1 = A \times \{ 0 \}$ and $B_1 = B \times \{ 1 \}$. Then $F(a) = (a, 0)$, $G(b) = (b, 0)$ so $F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A_1$ and $G: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B_1$ and $A_1 \cap B_1$. Therefore, $A_1 \approx A$ and $B_1 \approx B$.

:::

::: {#def-addition-cardinal-numbers}

# Addition

Let $\mathfrak{m}$ and $\mathfrak{n}$ be cardinal numbers. Take any sets $A$, $B$ such that $\mathscr{K}(A) = \mathfrak{m}$, $\mathscr{K}(B) = \mathfrak{n}$ and $A \cap B = \emptyset$. Then

$$\mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{n} = \mathscr{K}(A \cup B)$$
**Note**: By @lem-equinumerous-properties c, the result $\mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{n}$ does not depend upon the choice of $A$ and $B$.

Also the condition $A \cap B = \emptyset$ is important. For example, if $A = \{ 1, 2, 3 \}$ and $B = \{ 3, 4 \}$ then $\mathscr{K}(A) = 3$, $\mathscr{K}(B) = 2$, $\mathscr{K}(A \cup B) = 3$ where $\mathscr{K}(A) + \mathscr{K}(B) = 5 > \mathscr{K}(A \cup B) = 3$.  

:::

::: {#def-addition-cardinal-numbers}

## Multiplication and Exponentiation

Let $\mathfrak{m}$ and $\mathfrak{n}$ be cardinal numbers, and let $A$, $B$ be any sets such that $\mathscr{K}(A) = \mathfrak{m}$, $\mathscr{K}(B) = \mathfrak{n}$. Then

$$\mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n} = \mathscr{K}(A \times B),$$

and

$$\mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n}} = \mathscr{K}(A^B).$$
By @lem-equinumerous-properties a, b we know that $\mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n}$ and $\mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n}}$ do not depend upon the choice of $A$ and $B$.

:::

::: {#thm-cardinal-arithmetic}

a. $\mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{n} = \mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{m}$

b. $\mathfrak{m} + (\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}) = (\mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{n}) + \mathfrak{p}$

c. $\mathfrak{m} + 0 = \mathfrak{m}$ (Remember that $\mathscr{K}(\emptyset) = 0$)

d. $\mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n} = \mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{m}$

e. $\mathfrak{m} \times (\mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{p}) = (\mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n}) \times \mathfrak{p}$

f. $\mathfrak{m} \times 1 = \mathfrak{m}$ (Remember that $\mathscr{K}(P_1)$)

g. $\mathfrak{m} \times (\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}) = (\mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n}) + (\mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{p})$

h. $\mathfrak{m}^0 = 1$

i. $\mathfrak{n} \neq 0 \Longrightarrow 0^{\mathfrak{n}} = 0$

k. $\mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}} = \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n}} \times \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{p}}$

j. $(\mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n}})^{\mathfrak{p}} = \mathfrak{\mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{p}}}$

l. $2 \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \land 2 \leq_K \mathfrak{n} \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{n} \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n}$
:::

::: {.proof}

Let $\mathscr{K}(A) = \mathfrak{m}$, $\mathscr{K}(B) = \mathfrak{n}$ and $\mathscr{K}(C) = \mathfrak{p}$ where $A \cap B = \emptyset$, $A \cap C = \emptyset$, $B \cap C = \emptyset$ and $A \cap P_1 = \emptyset$:

a. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{n} & = \mathscr{K}(A \cup B) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(B \cup A); A \cup B = B \cup A \\
     & = \mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{m} 
    \end{aligned}$

b. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} + (\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}) & = \mathscr{K}(A \cup (B \cup C)) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}((A \cup B) \cup C)); A \cup (B \cup C) = (A \cup B) \cup C) \\
     & = (\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{m}) + \mathfrak{p}  
    \end{aligned}$

c. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} + 0 & = \mathscr{K}(A \cup \emptyset); A \cap \emptyset \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(A); A \cup \emptyset = A \\
     & = \mathfrak{m}  
    \end{aligned}$

d. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n} & = \mathscr{K}(A \times B) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(B \times A); A \times B \approx B \times A \\
     & = \mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{m}   
    \end{aligned}$

e. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} \times (\mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{p}) & = \mathscr{K}(A \times (B \times C)) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}((A \times B) \times C); A \times (B \times C) \approx (A \times B) \times C \\
     & = (\mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{m}) \times \mathfrak{p}   
    \end{aligned}$

f. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} \times 1 & = \mathscr{K}(A \times P_1) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(A); A \approx A \times P_1 \\
     & = \mathfrak{m}
    \end{aligned}$

g. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} \times (\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}) & = \mathscr{K}(A \times (B \cup C)) \\
      & = \mathscr{K}((A \times B) \cup (A \times C)); A \times (B \cup C) = A \times B \cup A \times C) \\
      & = (\mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n}) + (\mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{p})
    \end{aligned}$
     
h. $\begin{aligned}
    \mathfrak{m}^0 & = \mathscr{K}(A^{\emptyset}) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(\{ \emptyset \}); A^{\emptyset} = \{ \emptyset \} \\
     & = 1
    \end{aligned}$

i. Let $\mathfrak{n} \neq 0$ then $0^{\mathfrak{n}} = \mathscr{K}(\emptyset^B)$ where $B \neq \emptyset$. Because $\emptyset^B = \{ f \mid f: B \longrightarrow \emptyset \}$, but by @def-function $f$ is not a function. Therefore, $\emptyset^B = \emptyset$. So, $\mathscr{K}(\emptyset^B) = \mathscr{K}(\emptyset) = 0$ and $0^{\mathfrak{n}} = 0$ when $\mathfrak{n} \neq 0$.   

j. $\begin{aligned}
    \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}} & = \mathscr{K}(A^{B \cup C}) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(A^B \times A^C); A^{B \cup C} \approx A^B \times A^C \text{ when } B \cap C = \emptyset \\
     & = \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n}} \times \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{p}}
    \end{aligned}$

k. $\begin{aligned}
    (\mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n}})^{\mathfrak{p}} & = \mathscr{K}((A^B)^C) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(A^{B \times C}); (A^B)^C \approx A^{B \times C} \\
     & = \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{p}}
    \end{aligned}$

l. $\begin{aligned}
    \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{n} & = \mathscr{K}(A \cup B) \\
     & \iff A \cup B \leq A \times B \text{ if } 2 \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \land 2 \leq_K \mathfrak{n} \\
     & \iff \mathscr{K}(A \cup B) \leq \mathscr{K}(A \times B) \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{n} \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{n}  
    \end{aligned}$
:::

::: {#exr-less-equal-cardinal-numbers}

Assume $\mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{n}$ and $\mathfrak{p} \leq_K \mathfrak{q}$. Prove:

1. $\mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{p} \leq_K \mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{q}$

2. $\mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{p} \leq_K \mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{q}$

3. $\mathfrak{m} + (\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}) >_K 0 \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{p}} \leq_K \mathfrak{n}^{\mathfrak{q}}$

:::

::: {#sol-less-equal-cardinal-numbers}

 Also assume $\mathscr{K}(A) = \mathfrak{m}$, $\mathscr{K}(B) = \mathfrak{n}$, $\mathscr{K}(C) = \mathfrak{p}$, $\mathscr{K}(D) = \mathfrak{q}$ where $A \cap C = \emptyset$, $B \cap D = \emptyset$ and $(A \cap C) \cap B = \emptyset$:
 
1. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{n} \land \mathfrak{p} \leq_K \mathfrak{q} & \iff A \leq B \land C \leq D \\
     & \Longrightarrow A \cup C \leq B \cup D; \text{ where } B \cap D = \emptyset \\ 
     & \iff \mathscr{K}(A \cup C) \leq_K \mathscr{K}(B \cup D) \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{p} \leq_K \mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{q}
    \end{aligned}$

2. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{n} \land \mathfrak{p} \leq_K \mathfrak{q} & \iff A \leq B \land C \leq D \\
     & \Longrightarrow A \times C \leq B \times D \\ 
     & \iff \mathscr{K}(A \times C) \leq_K \mathscr{K}(B \times D) \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{p} \leq_K \mathfrak{n} \times \mathfrak{q}
    \end{aligned}$

3. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} + (\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}) >_K 0 & \iff \mathscr{K}(A \cup (B \cup C)) >_K \mathscr{K}(\emptyset) \\
     & \iff A \cup (B \cup C) > \emptyset \\
     & \Longrightarrow A \cup (B \cup C) \neq \emptyset \\
     & \Longrightarrow A^C \leq B^D \\
     & \iff \mathscr{K}(A^C) \leq_K \mathscr{K}(B^D) \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{p}} \leq_K \mathfrak{n}^{\mathfrak{q}} 
    \end{aligned}$

:::

::: {#thm-cardinal-number-positive-integers}

a. $\aleph_0 \times \aleph_0 = \aleph_0$

b. If $n$ is a positive integer, $\aleph_0^n = \aleph_0$

c. $0 <_K \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \aleph_0 \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{m} \times \aleph_0 = \aleph_0$

d. $\aleph_0 + \aleph_0 = \aleph_0$

e. $\mathfrak{m} \leq_K \aleph_0 \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{m} + \aleph_0 = \aleph_0$

:::

::: {.proof}

Assume $\mathscr{K}(A) = \mathfrak{m}$ where $\mathfrak{m} \leq_K \aleph_0$:

a. $\begin{aligned}
     \aleph_0 \times \aleph_0 & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P} \times \mathbb{P}) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}); \mathbb{P} \times \mathbb{P} \approx \mathbb{P} \\
     & = \aleph_0 
    \end{aligned}$

b. $\begin{aligned}
     \aleph_0^n & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}^{P_n}) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}); \mathbb{P}^{P_n} \approx \mathbb{P} \\
     & = \aleph_0
    \end{aligned}$

c. $\begin{aligned}
     0 <_K \mathfrak{m} \land \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \aleph_0 & \Longrightarrow 1 \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \land \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \aleph_0 \\
     & \Longrightarrow 1 \times \aleph_0 \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \times \aleph_0 \land \mathfrak{m} \times \aleph_0 \leq_K \aleph_0 \times \aleph_0 \\
     & \iff \aleph_0 \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \times \aleph_0 \land \mathfrak{m} \times \aleph_0 \leq_K \aleph_0 \\
     & \iff \mathbb{P} \leq A \times \mathbb{P} \land A \times \mathbb{P} \leq \mathbb{P} \\
     & \iff \mathbb{P} \approx A \times \mathbb{P} \\
     & \iff \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}) = \mathscr{K}(A \times \mathbb{P}) \\
     & \iff \aleph_0 = \mathfrak{m} \times \aleph_0  
    \end{aligned}$

d. $\begin{aligned}
     \aleph_0 + \aleph_0 & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}) + \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P} \times \{0\}) + \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P} \times \{1\}); \mathbb{P} \times \{0\} \approx \mathbb{P} \text{ and } \mathbb{P} \times \{1\} \approx \mathbb{P} \\
     & = \mathscr{K}((\mathbb{P} \times \{0\}) \cup (\mathbb{P} \times \{1\})) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}); (\mathbb{P} \times \{0\}) \cup (\mathbb{P} \times \{1\}) \approx \mathbb{P} \\
     & = \aleph_0 
    \end{aligned}$ 

e. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{m} + \aleph_0 & = \mathscr{K}(A) + \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(A \times \{0\}) + \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P} \times \{1\}); A \times \{0\} \approx A \land \mathbb{P} \times \{1\} \approx \mathbb{P} \\
     & = \mathscr{K}((A \times \{0\}) \cup (\mathbb{P} \times \{1\})) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{P}); (A \times \{0\}) \cup (\mathbb{P} \times \{1\}) \approx \mathbb{P} \text{ and } \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \aleph_0 \text{ so } A \text{ is denumerable or finite} \\
     & = \aleph_0 
    \end{aligned}$

:::

::: {#thm-cardinal-number-positive-integers-real}

a. $2^{\aleph_0} = \mathfrak{c}$

b. $\mathfrak{c} \times \mathfrak{c} = \mathfrak{c}$

c. $0 <_K \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{c} = \mathfrak{c}$

d. $\mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c} = \mathfrak{c}$

e. $\mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{c} = \mathfrak{c}$

f. $0 <_K \mathfrak{n} \leq_K \aleph_0 \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{c}^{\mathfrak{n}} = \mathfrak{c}$

g. $\mathfrak{c} <_K 2^\mathfrak{c}$

:::

::: {.proof}

Assume $\mathscr{K}(A) = \mathfrak{m}$ and $\mathscr{K}(B) = \mathfrak{n}$ where $\mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{c}$ and $\mathfrak{m} \leq_K \aleph_0$:

a. $\begin{aligned}
     2^{\aleph_0} & = \mathscr{K}(\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{P}}) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(\mathscr{P}(\mathbb{P})); \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{P}} \approx \mathscr{P}(\mathbb{P}) \\
     & = \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{R}); \mathscr{P}(\mathbb{P}) \approx \mathbb{R} \\
     & = \mathfrak{c}
    \end{aligned}$

b. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{c} \times \mathfrak{c} & = 2^{\aleph_0} \times 2^{\aleph_0}; \mathfrak{c} = 2^{\aleph_0} \\
     & = 2^{\aleph_0 + \aleph_0}; \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n} + \mathfrak{p}} = \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{n}} \times \mathfrak{m}^{\mathfrak{p}} \\
     & = 2^{\aleph_0}; \aleph_0 + \aleph_0 = \aleph_0 \\ 
     & = \mathfrak{c}; \mathfrak{c} = 2^{\aleph_0} 
    \end{aligned}$

c. $\begin{aligned}
     0 <_K \mathfrak{m} \land \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} & \Longrightarrow 1 \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \land \mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \\
     & \Longrightarrow 1 \times \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{c} \land \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \times \mathfrak{c} \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{c} \land \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \\
     & \iff \mathbb{R} \leq_K A \times \mathbb{R} \land A \times \mathbb{R} \leq_K \mathbb{R} \\
     & \iff \mathbb{R} \approx A \times \mathbb{R} \\
     & \iff \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{R}) = \mathscr{K}(A \times \mathbb{R}) \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{c} = \mathfrak{m} \times \mathfrak{c} \\ 
    \end{aligned}$

d. Because $0 \leq_K \mathfrak{c}$ and $\mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c}$ then by @exr-less-equal-cardinal-numbers 1 $\mathfrak{c} + 0 \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c}$. Therefore $\mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c}$ by @thm-cardinal-arithmetic c. Using the above result:  

   $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c} \land \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \times \mathfrak{c} & \iff \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c} \land \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{c} = \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c} 
    \end{aligned}$

e. Because $\mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c}$ and $0 \leq_K \mathfrak{m}$ then by @exr-less-equal-cardinal-numbers 1 $\mathfrak{c} + 0 \leq_K \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{c}$. Also by @thm-cardinal-arithmetic c $\mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{m}$. By a similar argument because $\mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{c}$ and $\mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c}$ we have that $\mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c}$. Using the above results:

   $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{m} \land  \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{c} & \iff \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} + \mathfrak{m} \land  \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{c} \land  \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{c} \leq_K \mathfrak{c} \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{c} = \mathfrak{m} + \mathfrak{c}  
    \end{aligned}$  

f. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathfrak{c}^{\mathfrak{m}} & = ({2^{\aleph_0}})^{\mathfrak{m}} \\
     & = 2^{\aleph_0 \times \mathfrak{m}} \\
     & = 2^{\mathfrak{m} \times \aleph_0} \\
     & = 2^{\aleph_0} \\
     & = \mathfrak{c}
    \end{aligned}$ 

g. $\begin{aligned}
     \mathbb{R} < \mathscr{P}(\mathbb{R}) & \iff \mathscr{K}(\mathbb{R}) <_K \mathscr{K}(\mathscr{P}(\mathbb{R})) \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{c} <_K \mathscr{K}(\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{R}}); \mathscr{P}(\mathbb{R}) \approx \{0,1\}^{\mathbb{R}} \\
     & \iff \mathfrak{c} <_K 2^{\mathfrak{c}} 
    \end{aligned}$

:::
